title: Fedi.Tips – An Unofficial Guide to Mastodon and the Fediverse

last_post.content:
For everyone who is #NewHere / #NeuHier, don't forget to post an #introduction with lots of hashtags to help people who share your interests find you (in general, hashtags are searchable but the full text of peole's posts is not).

Check out #FediTips or follow @feditips to get pointers as you settle in, or read through https://fedi.tips at your leisure

And don't be afraid to ask questions! We were all #NewHere once and had to learn the ropes. (Feel free to ask me if you're unsure about asking others :) )

Please don't clog up the Transgender Concerns Form with so many spurious reports that it becomes unusable, and the Missouri government gets Big Mad. Because that would be wrong. Here's a link to the form so you'll know exactly where not to do that: https://ago.mo.gov/file-a-complaint/transgender-center-concerns

title: Writing performant code with tidy tools

last_post.content:
New post on the #rstats tidyverse blog: 10-ish tips and tricks for speeding up tidy code🏎

When computational efficiency is the priority, switching from functions we love in dplyr and tidyr to the backend tools underlying them can result in substantial speedups.

https://www.tidyverse.org/blog/2023/04/performant-packages/

This is lovely: scroll up to ride an elevator from the Earth's surface to space, passing landmarks along the way. "Congratulations! You have made it 0.01% to the moon." (via @waxy) https://neal.fun/space-elevator/

title: Why is the Colorado river drying up? Feeding cows is a large part

last_post.content:
This is a must-read Vox piece on what's causing the water crisis in the West: Cows.

There's no way around it. We're draining the Colorado river for cows. Everything else is a literal drop in the bucket. Municipal conservation cannot solve the problem. Drying up golf courses and lawns cannot solve the problem.

It's. The. Cows.

https://www.vox.com/the-highlight/23655640/colorado-river-water-alfalfa-dairy-beef-meat

#climate #climatechange #agriculture #cattle #cows #colorado #coloradoriver #drought

thi.ng/umbrella livestream #4

This coming Sunday 2023-04-23 @ 20:00 CEST (UTC+2)

In this session I will be building a stripped down 2D version of the recently published Bubblemania mini-project, which is a great opportunity to talk about https://thi.ng/timestep, the newly released 180th(!) package in Umbrella, and of course, also to continue the discussion of various topics related to using https://thi.ng/rstream, https://thi.ng/rdom, https://thi.ng/transducers, https://thi.ng/geom, https://thi.ng/color etc. for realtime visualization purposes and/or artwork export. Should be fun!

title: How to pitch MIT Technology Review

last_post.content:
I normally post these on Twitter, but it just occurred to me I could try doing so here: MIT Technology Review has an open call for pitches, for our upcoming issue on ⚖️ethics⚖️. We're looking for *big* swings: features, investigations, profiles, and sharp essays at the intersection of #ethics and #technology. Rates: $1-2/word.

Pitch deadline is tomorrow: April 20. Short notice, I know! If you have an idea, but need a day or two to write up a pitch, send me an e-mail (see https://www.technologyreview.com/how-to-pitch-mit-technology-review/)

title: Pluralistic: What the fediverse (does/n’t) solve (23 Dec 2022) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
@JoeRess Jim hit the nail on the head with Mastodon's biggest win; Being able to pack up your social graph is very important.

@pluralistic refers to it as "Freedom of Exit" -- but, there's also "Freedom of Reach", that is just as important:

https://pluralistic.net/2022/12/23/semipermeable-membranes/

Keep chipping away at them, Joe! Great episode.

RT @nelsonfliu@twitter.com

Generative search engines are transforming how we find info, but are they trustworthy?

We evaluate Bing Chat, NeevaAI, http://perplexity.ai & YouChat—only 52% of statements are supported by cites and 75% of cites actually support their statements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09848

🧵

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/nelsonfliu/status/1649075151303221249

RT @rao2z@twitter.com

Interestingly, I was just telling someone today how several of the papers on "LLMs for Task Planning by Prompting" are rife with the Clever Hans effect (c.f. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clever_Hans ). I guess I will have to do a thread.. 2/

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/rao2z/status/1648876535070457856

title: The Hroswitha Club and the Impact of Women Book Collectors

last_post.content:
Check out @grubstreetwomen 's groundbreaking new book on the Hroswitha Club, founded by women book collectors excluded from Grolier membership--it's free to download until the 28th: https://www.cambridge.org/core/elements/hroswitha-club-and-the-impact-of-women-book-collectors/D4C67BCB0F31072BFCB12EC3544057BC

And/or (I'm doing both!) watch her talk on the club for the U. of Illinois Rare Book and Manuscript Library: https://youtu.be/9nHy5qbVJqo

ah, there we go, got that ✔️

For those curious, the technical path it took was:

1. Adding the link to the wikipedia.org template: https://gerrit.wikimedia.org/r/c/wikimedia/portals/+/908683

2. Merging the automated weekly portal build that fills in the template: https://gerrit.wikimedia.org/r/c/wikimedia/portals/deploy/+/909190

3. Updating the git submodule in the main deployment repository: https://gerrit.wikimedia.org/r/c/operations/mediawiki-config/+/909303

4. Actually deploying the change: https://sal.toolforge.org/log/lfLsj4cBxE1_1c7sI5sQ

title: Don't get it twisted: Fox's $787.5M defamation deal is record-setting, massive and painful, experts say

last_post.content:
Three prominent First Amendment lawyers uniformly agreed that Fox’s $787.5 million deal was record-setting, massive, and would be too painful for the network to ignore.

It's more than half of Fox's earnings from 2022.

Why they say you shouldn't believe the naysayers. https://lawandcrime.com/2020-election/dont-get-it-twisted-foxs-787-5m-defamation-deal-is-record-setting-massive-and-painful-experts-say/

title: The Future of Social Media Is a Lot Less Social

last_post.content: Thoughtful column from NYTimes Brian Chen on possible futures for social media - draws heavily on our Three-Legged Stool whitepaper: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/19/technology/personaltech/tiktok-twitter-facebook-social.html

Finally! #Grambank is out!

Grambank is a new database that documents patterns of grammatical variation in over 2400 of the world’s languages.

All available here: https://grambank.clld.org/

Press Release: https://www.mpg.de/20186271/0418-evan-grambank-shows-the-diversity-of-the-world-s-languages-150495-x

Tech companies have gotten increasingly secretive about the data, scraped from the internet without compensation or consent, used to train their AI models. So we looked closer. Here's our analysis of the 15 million websites in just one highly-filtered CommonCrawl web scrape-used to train models like Google's T5 & Facebook's LLaMA.
We found
-the copyright symbol appears >200M times
-pirated sites, 1 for e-books
-half of the top 10 were news sites https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/interactive/2023/ai-chatbot-learning

Born #onthisday in 1840, the French symbolist artist Odilon Redon. Known for his surreal and often haunting imagery, some of his most stunning works are his illustrations for Flaubert's failed masterpiece Temptation of St Anthony: https://buff.ly/3nbwgzy #OTD #art #symbolism #religion #illustration

New puzzle alert! Jellyfish Dreams puzzle https://n-e-r-v-o-u-s.com/shop/product.php?code=408

173 pieces including 8 sea-themed whimsies, features a new cut style we created specifically for the puzzle called Coral.

title: Google’s Rush to Win in AI Led to Ethical Lapses, Employees Say

last_post.content:
Important reporting by Davey Alba and Julia Love on Google's rush to compete with OpenAI and sloppily pushing things out via a "code red", ignoring the weak ethics review guidelines already in place.

In particular, I'm glad they gave prominent attention to @Mahdi and the way they've censored his work on LLMs. Leadership did everything they could to stop this paper from being published, while lavishing praise on silly Medium posts by senior VPs.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2023-04-19/google-bard-ai-chatbot-raises-ethical-concerns-from-employees

title: Google DeepMind: Bringing together two world-class AI teams

last_post.content:
I'm not sure what this is announcing other than Alphabet / Google are reorganizing some internal departments.

Also, lol @ opening with "We’ve been an AI-first company since 2016"

https://blog.google/technology/ai/april-ai-update/

title: Worst Practices in Software Development: Julia Evans doesn't read the documentation

last_post.content:
had fun being a guest on Brett Slatkin's new "worst practices" show, talking about how I don't read documentation. The show is about the "bad" things we all do when writing software. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=krMw1QTP2no

I love that the episodes are only 5 minutes, and so far my reaction to all of them has been "I do that too! who DOESN'T do that?" :)

i am giving the talk in a week, you can attend in toronto or virtually - https://causalislands.com.

and for the afterparty (open to the public) i will be doing a brief revue of my portfolio of art and comedy apps that i have made over the years

📝 D2CSE: Difference-Aware Deep Continuous Prompts for Contrastive Sentence Embeddings 📚👾

"Difference-aware Deep continuous prompt for Contrastive Sentence Embeddings (D2CSE) learns sentence embeddings that are exceptional to distinguish a subtle difference between similar sentences by employing a simple neural architecture for continuous prompts." [gal30b+] 🤖 #CL #AI

⚙️ https://github.com/princeton-nlp/SimCSE
🔗 https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08991v1 #arxiv

Check out @grubstreetwomen 's groundbreaking new book on the Hroswitha Club, founded by women book collectors excluded from Grolier membership--it's free to download until the 28th: https://www.cambridge.org/core/elements/hroswitha-club-and-the-impact-of-women-book-collectors/D4C67BCB0F31072BFCB12EC3544057BC

This is why I don't fly or drive a car or eat much meat: Not for the carbon footprint (a bogus concept anyway) but the peer pressure.

https://mastodon.social/@Snoro/110228045387516982

A new Misskey/Calckey client for iOS just came out!

It’s called Kimis. Unlike other clients, the interface is accessible in English.

This is much needed because Misskey doesn’t use Mastodon’s API—it has its own. Which means most Fediverse clients aren’t usable with Misskey.

But that’s okay because Kimis is here to the rescue!

The download link is here:

https://apps.apple.com/ca/app/kimis-a-client-for-misskey/id1667275125

Also see screenshots of me running Kimis with my Calckey account on vancity.social.

@fediversenews

title: Donations are needed now for Cambridge Day - Cambridge Day

last_post.content:
The last local print newspaper in Cambridge (the Cambridge Chronicle) has eliminated all investment in local news, which has left the (online-only) Cambridge Day as the only remaining local news source. In order to take that role on appropriately, the paper's advisory board has decided to pursue a crowdfunding strategy to ensure the long term survival of this vital local news source.

Announcement: https://www.cambridgeday.com/2023/04/18/donations-are-needed-now-for-cambridge-day/

Crowdfunding link: https://gofund.me/2b1e09ad

We’re back with our newsletter!

https://posit.co/blog/posit-glimpse-newsletter-05/

posit::glimpse() is the same glimpse of our tools and how to use them, but now with our new name.

In this edition: Learn how to position text and images in Shiny apps, work on your data science compositions in Quarto, transpose data with tidyverse, & work with teams in R and Python.

We posit you’ll find something useful, and positive you’ll learn something new!

#rstats #python #quartopub #tidyverse #tidymodels

Doing sentiment analysis?

Working with non-English texts?

Adam Crymble’s English translation of @jenniferisasi’s lesson teaches you how, using a Spanish-language novel as its case study.

With thanks to Shuang Du, @apjanco + Rolando Rodriguez

RT @nelsonfliu@twitter.com

Generative search engines are transforming how we find info, but are they trustworthy?

We evaluate Bing Chat, NeevaAI, http://perplexity.ai & YouChat—only 52% of statements are supported by cites and 75% of cites actually support their statements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09848

title: Work with the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press

last_post.content: Hello #legal mastodon! The Reporters Committee for freedom of the Press is hiring three (3!) full-time positions for media and #1A attorneys in DC and around the country. RCFP is looking to hire: (1) a Staff Attorney to support the Reporters Committee’s Local Legal Initiative (LLI) and other legal programming; (2) a Staff Attorney to lead our amicus brief practice; and (3) an Oklahoma Local Legal Initiative Attorney. Details here: https://www.rcfp.org/work-at-rcfp/#ft Please share!

Grambank is a new database that documents patterns of grammatical variation in over 2400 of the world’s languages.

All available here: https://grambank.clld.org/
